I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Pakistan requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in early 
2004  to  provide  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  purpose  of  streamlining  procedures  to 
minimize delays at the start-up stage of development projects, improve project implementation, 
and facilitate the realization of expected outcomes and results of projects. It was agreed with the 
Government that the focus of this TA would be on addressing delays between the stages of 
approval  and  effectiveness  of  ADB  projects,  and  from  effectiveness  to  award  of  the  first 
substantive contract.  It was recognized, however, that measures introduced to address start-up 
delays in ADB projects under this TA would also have broader relevance in addressing such 
delays generally across all development projects. The concept paper for the TA was approved 
on 9 September 2004.1  From 22 to 30 November 2004, an ADB Fact-Finding Mission held 
discussions  with  key  Government  counterparts  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
Government  on  the  TA  objectives,  scope,  components,  implementation,  financing 
arrangements, and outline terms of reference.  
 
II.   ISSUES 
2.  The economic performance of Pakistan has steadily improved during the past few years. 
GDP growth increased from 3.4% in the fiscal year (FY) 2002, to 5.4% in FY 2003 and 6.4% in 
FY2004. External debt liabilities decreased and foreign exchange reserves increased. With the 
improved macroeconomic situation and increased fiscal space, the Government has a renewed 
emphasis on enhancing the scope of its development program and effective implementation of 
development projects in the various sectors of the economy – infrastructure, agriculture and 
rural development, social sectors, and others – to reduce the incidence of poverty. 
 
3.  ADB is one of Pakistan’s largest development partners and has an ongoing portfolio of 
54 loans (42 projects) for a total of $4.6 billion in the country.  Under the Country Strategy and 
Program Update (2005–2006), ADB has committed to provide close to $2 billion of development 
assistance for 23 loans to Pakistan.  The Government has agreed that there is a need to ensure 
timely and effective implementation of ADB-assisted development projects for maximum returns 
and accrual of desired benefits from such projects. 
 
4.  The Government has placed heightened emphasis on improving the implementation of 
development projects and utilization of the Public Sector Development Program (PSDP).  The 
Planning Commission has recently undertaken a series of measures to improve utilization of 
PSDP and strengthen monitoring and evaluation of development projects.  In this regard, ADB 
is providing assistance to the Planning Commission through a TA to develop a more effective 
monitoring and evaluation system for development projects.2  ADB is also providing a separate 
TA  to  build  the  capacity  of  project  management  units  (PMUs)  for  improved  financial 
management of development projects.3 
 
5.  Significant  start-up  delays  in  development  projects  adversely  affect  achievement  of 
project  goals,  contribute  to  cost-overruns,  increase  the  cost  of  borrowing  by  Government 
(commitment charges need to be paid on undisbursed amounts of Ordinary Capital Resources

(OCR) loans) and result in suboptimal development results.   With regard to approval of a loan 
and its effectiveness date, this phase can be split up into two sub-phases, that is, from loan 
approval to loan signing, and from loan signing to loan effectiveness. In a recent study, that 
estimated time taken for loan signing and effectivity for 10 selected ADB projects, it was found 
that loan signing took place, on average, 8 months after approval, while loan effectiveness, on 
average, was achieved in over 6 months after loan signing.4  Further substantial delays are 
encountered in the next phase, that is, between the loan effectiveness and start of actual 
implementation, with the award of the first contract. The time taken for projects in Pakistan to 
pass through these two stages has, in the past, averaged as much as 24 months. This TA is 
primarily  concerned  with  investigating  causes  for  such  start-up  delays  and  proposing 
recommendations and initiating measures to reduce such delays. 
 
6.   The time taken between loan approval and signing is significantly longer than what it 
should be for such a routine operational procedure – which should normally be completed 
without delay.  The main cause of the delay is the delay in the authorization to sign the loan 
agreement by the federal Government, and project agreements by the concerned provincial 
governments for provincial loans. 
7.  Second, while the agreed upon period between loan signing and effectiveness is 90 
days, in practice, effectiveness occurs much later, in some cases as much as up to 12 months 
or more. Delays in this regard are caused by two factors.  First, there are delays in provision of 
the standard legal opinions by the federal and provincial governments.  Further, the legal 
opinions that are provided are at times found unacceptable to ADB and have to be revised, 
causing  further  delays.    The  second  cause  for  delayed  effectiveness  is  the  delay  in  the 
Government’s compliance with other effectiveness conditions, such as those that relate to 
establishment of project management units, appointment of project directors and other staff, as 
well as other related conditions.  Among others, a main reason for this delay is the lack of funds 
to undertake recurrent expenditure relating to payment of salaries, etc. of staff appointed in the 
PMUs before loan effectiveness.  In this regard, there is need to ensure that loan effectiveness 
conditions are fully agreed between Government and ADB and are practical and achievable 
within the stipulated period for loan effectiveness. 
8.  Third, there are significant delays between loan effectiveness and award of first contract 
for start of actual implementation.  One reason is that participation of executing agencies (EAs) 
in the planning and design phase of projects is often not adequate, as a result of which they do 
not have full understanding of, and commitment to projects, and pay insufficient attention to 
advance procurement actions in the processing stage and subsequent project implementation.  
To ensure full engagement of EAs throughout the project cycle, starting from loan processing, 
the Government and ADB agreed in the Memorandum of Understanding of the 2003 Country 
Portfolio Review Mission (CPRM) to establish core project management units (CPMUs) at the 
loan fact-finding stage. It was agreed that staff of CPMUs would be responsible for participating 
at all stages of loan preparation including participating in loan fact-finding missions; preparation 
and approval of PC-Is prior to loan negotiations so that the current delays in the approval of 
these documents is minimized; and preparation of draft invitation documents for recruitment of 
consultants as well as draft prequalification and tender documents to minimize subsequent 
common  delays  in  consultant  recruitment  and  procurement.    The  CPMU  would  then  be 
converted to a PMU following loan approval.  It was also agreed that the CPMUs would be

However, there are some problems in implementing this agreement.5 
9.  Another reason for the delay between loan effectiveness and award of first contract is 
the lengthy procurement and consultant recruitment procedures of Government and ADB and 
the need for EAs to obtain frequent Government and ADB approvals at different stages of the 
project implementation cycle.  The often-complex procurement procedures are also not well 
understood by EAs and PMUs, especially in case of newly posted project staff. In this regard, 
there is a need for a review of existing Government and ADB procurement and consultant 
recruitment procedures.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The goal of the TA is to reduce the current excessive delays in the start-up phase of 
development projects. The purpose of the TA is to assist the federal and provincial governments 
and  ADB  in  streamlining  procedures  and  operational  modalities  during  the  start-up  phase 
between loan approval and actual implementation of development projects.  
 
 
11.  The outputs of the TA include (i) recommendations and an implementation plan for 
reducing start-up delays in projects from a diagnostic study on comprehensive identification 
reasons for such delays; (ii) systemic improvements in the Economic Affairs Division (EAD) and 
Foreign Aid sections of provincial planning and development departments (P&DDs) to increase 
their effectiveness in addressing start-up delays in projects; and (iii) capacity building for EAD 
and the Foreign Aid Sections of the P&DDs to enable them to effectively monitor, facilitate, and 
follow up with EAs and PMUs to reduce start-up delays in projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, from March 2005 to August 2006, in two 
phases. In phase 1 (March–June 2005 (4 months)) a comprehensive diagnostic study will be 
carried out.  The study will identify key issues and factors causing delays in the start-up stage, 
and provide recommendations along with an implementation plan to reduce such delays.  The 
study will include a review of existing Government procedures for preparing and approving PC-I 
and  PC-II,  and  ADB’s  procurement  and  consultant  recruitment  procedures  –  as  well  as 
operational  procedures  of  other  development  partners,  particularly  the  World  Bank.    A 
workshop will be conducted to share the results of the diagnostic study with all stakeholders.  
Simultaneous to the diagnostic study, and in an effort to better understand issues related to 
start-up delays, and to recommend appropriate changes and improvements in operational 
policies and procedures in the implementation plan, a pilot activity will be carried out.  This will 
involve provision of support to EAD and provincial P&DDs to follow up and facilitate the start-up 
of loans approved in 2004 to minimize the time taken from loan approval to effectiveness and 
award of first contracts.  The pilot will also support EAD and provincial P&DDs to ensure the 
earliest award of first contracts for loans approved in 2002–2003 for which such contracts have 
not yet been awarded. 
                                                 
5  With regard to the establishment of the CPMUs, the Government has agreed to urgently resolve the outstanding  
issue of the establishment of revolving funds that would finance the CPMUs before loan approval.

4 
13.  In phase II (July 2005 to August 2006 (14 months)), the recommendations for systemic 
improvements and capacity building for EAD and the Foreign Aid sections of P&DDs coming out 
of the diagnostic study (and early lessons from the pilot activity) will be implemented.  This will 
include:  (i)  operationalizing  a  management  information  system  (MIS)  to  enable  EAD  and 
provincial P&DDs to effectively monitor and follow up on start-up activities for projects;6 (ii) 
supporting operationalizing and strengthening of CPMUs; (iii) producing a set of model project 
administration manuals (PAMs) which are simple and user friendly; (iv) assisting ADB project 
preparation teams on project processing and advance procurement actions; and (v) conducting 
of  training  workshops  for  staff  of  EAD,  P&DD,  and  relevant  EAs  and  PMUs.      The  TA 
Framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $570,000 equivalent, comprising $95,000 in 
foreign exchange and $475,000 in local currency equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. ADB will provide $450,000 equivalent, which will cover the 
entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $355,000  equivalent  of  the  local  currency  cost.  The 
Government will finance the remaining local currency cost of $120,000 equivalent in kind. 
Details of cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be EAD which will be responsible for undertaking 
project activities at the federal level and coordinating with the concerned federal and provincial 
government departments and other stakeholders as required. EAD will appoint an officer of the 
level of Joint Secretary as TA manager supported by two staff members from EAD (ADB unit), 
and notify a TA Steering Committee headed by Secretary EAD with members from the Planning 
Commission, Ministry of Law and Justice, and provincial P&DDs.  The TA manager will act as 
the secretary of the TA Steering Committee. The respective provincial P&DDs will be the 
implementing agencies for the TA and will be responsible for undertaking and coordinating TA 
activities at the provincial level. The Chiefs of Foreign Aid sections in the provincial P&DDs will 
be the focal points for the TA at the provincial level, and will be assisted by two staff members of 
the respective sections. Counterpart staff associated with the TA will perform their functions side 
by side with their routine official responsibilities. 
 
16.  The consulting services for the TA total 54 person-months: 51 for domestic consultants 
and 3 for international consultant.  The domestic consultancy component will comprise 18 
person-months for the team leader, 28 person-months for short-term specialists, and 5 person-
months  for  a  MIS/software  specialist.  The  team  leader  will  have  experience  in  project 
management,  public  sector  planning  and  developmental  management  as  well  as  capacity 
building and procurement.  There will be 4 short-term specialists, one in each province.  The 
specialists will have experience in project management, institutional development and capacity 
building, and procurement. The MIS/software specialist will have experience in developing and 
operationalizing project management software systems.  The international consultant will have 
experience  in  project  management,  institutional  development  and  capacity  building,  and 
procurement.  ADB will engage individual consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the

17.  The consultants will prepare (i) an inception report 3 weeks after the start of the TA for 
discussion  by  the  TA  Steering  Committee;  (ii)  prepare  quarterly  progress  reports  to  be 
submitted to the TA Steering Committee; and (iii) a final report after the conclusion of consulting 
services.  Copies of all reports will also be submitted to ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Pakistan  for  Streamlining  Procedures  to  Reduce  Delays  in  Start-up  of 
Development Projects, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

B.  Institutional  and  Capacity  Building  Specialists  (4  domestic,  total  of  28  person- 
months) 
4.   The short-term specialists (one of each in the four provinces) will have at least 5 years 
experience  in  project  management,  institutional  development  and  capacity  building,  and 
procurement.  The specialists will report to the Team Leader. They will be required to put in two 
months of work each during phase 1 of the TA (March–June 2005) and the remaining five 
months each during phase 2 of the TA (July 2005–August 2006) as per work plan designed by 
the team leader in the first month of TA implementation. 
 
5.  The key responsibilities of the specialists are to 
(i)  assist the team leader in mapping the Government and ADB’s project start-up 
processes and procedures; 
(ii)  assist in conducting a diagnostic study of the Government and ADB’s operational 
policies and procedures to identify key factors responsible for start-up delays in 
projects; 
(iii)  execute  a  pilot  activity  for  supporting  the  respective  provincial  P&DDs  in 
implementing an effective monitoring, follow-up, and facilitation system for the 
different start-up stages of projects; 
(iv)  assist in preparing an implementation plan to reduce start-up delays in projects; 
(v)  support the respective P&DDs in executing the implementation plan;  
(vi)  support provincial–level EAs in operationalizing and strengthening  CPMUs; 
(vii)  assist in assessing capacity–building needs for respective P&DDs; 
(viii)  implement capacity–building activities in the respective P&DDs; 
(ix)  assist in organizing, coordinating, and documenting meetings and dissemination 
and capacity–building workshops with stakeholders; 
(x)  coordinate to the greatest extent possible with development partners;  
(xi)  coordinate  overall  TA  activities  at  the  respective  provincial  P&DDs  and 
EAs/PMUs; and 
(xii)  assist  the  team  leader  in  preparing  the  inception  report,  quarterly  progress 
reports, and final report.

6.   The specialist will have at least 5 years experience in MIS/software development, and 
specific experience in developing and operationalizing project monitoring and tracking systems.  
The specialist will report to the team leader, and will be expected to provide input during July–
November 2005.

7.  The key responsibilities are to 
(i)  Develop an understanding of the Government and ADB systems and procedures 
involved in the start up of development projects; 
(ii)  study the MIS/project monitoring system established under the ADB– funded TA 
on Strengthening Portfolio Performance and Monitoring; 
(iii)  assess the feasibility of extending the MIS established under the above TA to 
include monitoring of start-up activities.   Make modifications in the MIS, and/or 
develop  additional  software  as  necessary  to  include  monitoring  of  start-up 
activities; 
(iv)  operationalize the MIS in EAD and provincial P&DDs; and 
(v)  organize and deliver formal training in use of MIS for relevant staff of EAD and 
P&DD. 
  
D.  Project Management and Institutional Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
8.  The specialist will have at least 10 years experience in project management, institutional 
development and capacity building, and procurement, and will have previous work experience 
with ADB funded projects and TAs. The international consultant will report to the team leader, 
and will be expected to provide 1.5 person-months of input during phase 1 of the TA (March–
June 2005), and the remaining in phase 2 (July 2005 –August 2006) as per the agreed–upon 
work plan. 
9.  The key responsibilities are to 
(i)  share  with  executing  and  implementing  agencies  lessons  learned  and  best 
practice from international experience in the People’s Republic of China and 
other countries in reducing start-up project delays in ADB–assisted projects;  
(ii)  assess the relevance of such experience with the situation in Pakistan.  Suggest 
measures to reducing start-up delays in development projects in the country; 
(iii)  propose  actions  to  improve  harmonization  of  ADB  and  Government  project 
procedures to reduce delays, based on experience in other countries; 
(iv)  propose  measures  to  simplify  and  improve  PAMs  and  other  relevant  ADB 
documents and handbooks to make these more user friendly for executing and 
implementing agencies; 
(v)  provide written inputs for the diagnostic study and implementation plan.   Assist 
team leader, as needed, in undertaking the implementation plan; and   
(vi)  undertake other assignments as requested by the team leader.
